Abstract

Cross-silo Federated learning (FL) has become a promising tool in machine learning applications for healthcare. It allows hospitals/institutions to train models with sufficient data while the data is kept private. To make sure the FL model is robust when facing heterogeneous data among FL clients, most efforts focus on personalizing models for clients. However, the latent relationships between clients’ data are ignored. In this work, we focus on a special non-iid FL problem, called Domain-mixed FL, where each client’s data distribution is assumed to be a mixture of several predefined domains. Recognizing the diversity of domains and the similarity within domains, we propose a novel method, FedDAR, which learns a domain shared representation and domain-wise personalized prediction heads in a decoupled manner. For simplified linear regression settings, we have theoretically proved that FedDAR  enjoys a linear convergence rate. For general settings, we have performed intensive empirical studies on both synthetic and real-world medical datasets which demonstrate its superiority over prior FL methods.

1 Introduction

Federated learning (FL) [38] is a machine learning approach that allows many clients(e.g. mobile devices or organizations) to collaboratively train a model without sharing the data. It has great potential to resolve the dilemma in real-world machine learning applications, especially in the domain of healthcare. A robust and generalizable model in medical application usually requires a large amount of diverse data to train. However, collecting a large-scale centralized dataset could be expensive or even impractical due to the constraints from regulatory, ethical and legal challenges, data privacy and protection [47].

While promising, applying FL to real-world problems has many technical challenges. One eminent challenge is data heterogeneity. Data across the clients are assumed to be independently and identically distributed (iid) by many FL algorithms. But this assumption rarely holds in the real world. It has been shown that non-iid data distributions will cause the failure of standard FL strategies such as FedAvg [25, 49, 26, 31]. As an ideal model that can perform well on all clients may not exist, it requires FL algorithms to personalize the model for different data distributions.

Prior theoretical work [36] shows that it is impossible to improve performances on all clients without making assumptions about the client’s data distributions. Past works on personalized FL methods [36, 49, 16, 35, 11] make their own assumptions and tailor their methods to those assumptions. In this paper, we propose a new and more realistic assumption where each client’s data distribution is a mixture of several predefined domains. We call our problem setting Domain-mixed FL. It is inspired by the fact that the diversity of the medical data can be attributed to some known concept of domains, such as different demographic/ethnic groups of patients  [52, 46, 44], different manufacturers or protocols/workflows of image scanners [37, 5], and so on. Despite of the domain shifts between data domains, same domain at different clients are usually considered to have the same distribution. The data heterogeneity between FL clients actually comes from the distinct mixtures of diverse domains at clients. Furthermore, it is necessary to address the ubiquitous issue of domain shifts in healthcare data. For instance, different ethic groups could have significant differences in disease patterns and treatment responses  [52, 46, 44]. In addition, one ethic group could be a majority in one location/client, but a minority in another location/client; the mixture or composition of ethnicity could be different in local study cohorts. To reduce the potential bias in the FL model, we need put ethniciy related domain-wise personalization into our algorithm design. Real world applications like this motivate us to personalize model for each domain instead of client.

FedEM[36] and FedMinMax[45] makes similar assumption on data distribution as ours. However, FedEM assumes the domains are unknown and tries to learn a linear combination of several shared component models with personalized mixture weights through an EM-like algorithm. FedMinMax doesn’t acknowledge the domain shift between domains and still aims to learn one shared model across domains by adapting minmax optimization to FL setting .

Our Contributions. We formulate the proposed problem setting, Domain-mixed FL. Through our analysis, we find prior FL methods, both generic FL methods like FedAvg [38], and personalized FL methods like FedRep [6], are sub-optimal under our setting. To address this issue, we propose a new algorithm, Federated Domain-Aware Representation Learning (FedDAR). FedDAR learns a shared model for all the clients but embedded with domain-wise personalized modules. The model contains two parts: an shared encoder across all domains and a multi-headed predictor whose heads are associated with domains. For an input from one specific domain, the model extracts representation via the shared encoder and then use the corresponding head to make the prediction. FedDAR decouples the learning of the encoder and heads by alternating between the updates of the encoder and the heads. It allows the clients to run many local updates on the heads without overfitting on domains with limited data samples. This also leads to faster convergence and better performed model. FedDAR also adapts different aggregation strategies for the two parts. We use a weighted average operation to aggregate the local updates for the encoder. With additional sample re-weighting, the overall training objective is equally weighted for each domain to encourage the fairness among domains. While for the heads, we propose a novel second-order aggregation algorithm to improve the optimality of aggregated heads.

We theoretically show our method enjoys nice properties like linear convergence and small sample complexity in a linear case. Through extensive experiments on both synthetic and real-world datasets, we demonstrate that FedDAR significantly improves performance over the state-of-the-art personalized FL methods. To the best of our knowledge, our paper is among the first efforts in domain-wise personalized federated learning that achieve such superior performance.

2 Related work

Besides the literature we have discussed above, other works on personalization and fairness in federated learning are also closely related to our work.

Personalized Federated Learning.

Personalized federated learning has been studied from a variety of perspectives: i) local fine-tuning [58, 61] ii) meta-learning [2, 13, 25, 28] iii) local/global model interpolation  [11, 7, 35]. iv) clustered FL that partition clients into clusters and learn optimal model for each cluster [49, 35, 16]. v) Multi-Task Learning(MTL) [55, 51, 64] [19, 18, 53, 22, 30] vi) local representations or heads for clients [1, 34, 6]. vii) personalized model through hypernetwork or super model [50, 3, 60]. The personalization module in our approach is similar to vi). However, the targets we are personalizing the model for are the domains instead of clients.

Fairness in Federated Learning.

There are two commonly used definitions of fairness in existing FL works. One is client fairness, usually formulated as client parity (CP), which requires clients to have similar performance. A few works [30, 32, 40, 62, 67] have studied on this. Another is group fairness. In the centralized setting, the fundamental tradeoff between group fairness and accuracy has been studied [39, 59, 68], and various fair training algorithms have been proposed[48, 24, 63, 65, 20]. Since the notions of group fairness is the same in FL setting, most of existing FL works adapt methods from centralized setting [66, 12, 14, 4, 8]. In this work, our method is not designed specifically for certain group fairness notions like demographic parity. Instead, we aim to achieve the best possible performance for each domain through personalization, admitting the difference between data domains. Moreover, our concept of data domains is not limited as demographic groups. It can also be applied to any other mixture of domain data, as long as our assumptions hold.

3 Problem: Domain-mixed Federated Learning

Notations. Federated learning involves multiple clients. We denote number of clients as n𝑛n. We use i∈[n]≜{1,2,…,n}𝑖delimited-[]𝑛≜12…𝑛i\in[n]\triangleq\{1,2,...,n\} to index each client. In real practice, client i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n] has a finite number, say Lisubscript𝐿𝑖L_{i}, of data samples, i.e., 𝒮i={(𝒙ij,yij)}j=1Lisubscript𝒮𝑖superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑖𝑗𝑗1subscript𝐿𝑖\mathcal{S}_{i}=\{({\bm{x}}_{i}^{j},y_{i}^{j})\}_{j=1}^{L_{i}}. L=∑i=1nLi𝐿superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝐿𝑖L=\sum_{i=1}^{n}L_{i} denotes the total number of data samples.

Problem Formulation of Domain-mixed Federated Learning. We introduce a new formulation of FL problem by assuming each clients’ local data distribution is a weighted mixture of M𝑀M domain specific distributions. Specifically, we use {𝒟~m}m=1Msuperscriptsubscriptsubscript~𝒟𝑚𝑚1𝑀\{\tilde{\mathcal{D}}_{m}\}_{m=1}^{M} to denote data distributions from M𝑀M predefined domains. For client i𝑖i, its local data distribution is 𝒟i=∑mπi,m​𝒟~msubscript𝒟𝑖subscript𝑚subscript𝜋𝑖𝑚subscript~𝒟𝑚{\mathcal{D}}_{i}=\sum_{m}\pi_{i,m}\tilde{\mathcal{D}}_{m} where the mixing coefficients πi,msubscript𝜋𝑖𝑚\pi_{i,m} stand for the probabilities of client i𝑖i’s data sample coming from domain m𝑚m. Take medical application as an example, different hospitals are clients and different ethnic groups are domains. Each ethnic group have different health data while each hospital’s data is a mix of ethnic group data.

Further, the domains of the data samples are assumed to be known. We use a triplet of variables (𝒙,y,z)𝒙𝑦𝑧({\bm{x}},y,z) to represent the input features, label and domain. The goal of our problem is to learn a model f​(𝒙,z)𝑓𝒙𝑧f({\bm{x}},z) that can perform well in every domain, as shown by the following learning objective,

minf⁡ℛ​(f):=1M​∑m=1Mℛm​(f​(⋅,m))assignsubscript𝑓ℛ𝑓1𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscriptℛ𝑚𝑓⋅𝑚\min_{f}{\mathcal{R}}(f):=\frac{1}{M}\sum_{m=1}^{M}{\mathcal{R}}_{m}(f(\cdot,m)) (1)

where ℛm​(f​(⋅,m))=𝔼(𝒙,m)∼𝒟~m​[ℓ​(f​(𝒙,m),y)]subscriptℛ𝑚𝑓⋅𝑚subscript𝔼similar-to𝒙𝑚subscript~𝒟𝑚delimited-[]ℓ𝑓𝒙𝑚𝑦{\mathcal{R}}_{m}(f(\cdot,m))=\mathbb{E}_{({\bm{x}},m)\sim\tilde{{\mathcal{D}}}_{m}}[\ell(f({\bm{x}},m),y)]. Our problem focuses on the setting that each domain have a different conditioned label distribution, i.e., Pm​(y|𝒙)subscript𝑃𝑚conditional𝑦𝒙P_{m}(y|{\bm{x}}) is different in each domain m𝑚m.

3.1 Comparison with Prior Domain-unaware FL Problem Formulations

Our FL problem introduces the concept of the domain and focuses on the model’s performance in each domain. Many prior FL formulations does not recognize the existence of the domains. For example, the original federated learning algorithms like FedAvg [38], FedProx [31] learn a globally shared model that via minimizing the averaged risk, i.e., minf⁡1n​∑iℛi​(f)subscript𝑓1𝑛subscript𝑖subscriptℛ𝑖𝑓\min_{f}\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i}{\mathcal{R}}_{i}(f). Some variants consider the fairness across the clients. To do so they optimize the worst client’s performance, instead of the averaged performance, i.e., minf⁡maxi⁡ℛi​(f)subscript𝑓subscript𝑖subscriptℛ𝑖𝑓\min_{f}\max_{i}{\mathcal{R}}_{i}(f). Further, personalized FL algorithms, such as FedRep [6], customize the model’s prediction for each client whose objective is minfi:i∈[n]⁡1n​∑i=1nℛi​(fi)subscript:subscript𝑓𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑛1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscriptℛ𝑖subscript𝑓𝑖\min_{f_{i}:i\in[n]}\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}{\mathcal{R}}_{i}(f_{i}).

All the FL algorithms mentioned above will lead sub-optimal solutions to our problem since they do not make domain specific predictions. We illustrate this point by the following toy example of linear regression: We assume the data in m𝑚m’th domain is generated via the following procedure: 𝒙∈ℝd𝒙superscriptℝ𝑑{\bm{x}}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} is i.i.d sampled from a distribution p​(𝒙)𝑝𝒙p({\bm{x}}) with mean zero and covariance 𝑰dsubscript𝑰𝑑{\bm{I}}_{d}. The label y∈ℝ𝑦ℝy\in\mathbb{R} obeys y=𝒙⊤​𝑩∗​𝒘m∗𝑦superscript𝒙topsuperscript𝑩subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑚y={\bm{x}}^{\top}{\bm{B}}^{*}{\bm{w}}^{*}_{m} where 𝑩∗∈ℝd×ksuperscript𝑩superscriptℝ𝑑𝑘{\bm{B}}^{*}\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times k} is ground truth linear embedding shared by all domains, and 𝒘m∗∈ℝksubscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑚superscriptℝ𝑘{\bm{w}}^{*}_{m}\in\mathbb{R}^{k} is the linear head specific to domain m𝑚m. Under this setting, 𝒟~msubscript~𝒟𝑚\tilde{\mathcal{D}}_{m} stands for data (𝒙,y)𝒙𝑦({\bm{x}},y) where x∼p​(𝒙)similar-to𝑥𝑝𝒙x\sim p({\bm{x}}) and y=𝒙⊤​𝑩∗​𝒘m∗𝑦superscript𝒙topsuperscript𝑩superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑚y={\bm{x}}^{\top}{\bm{B}}^{*}{\bm{w}}_{m}^{*}. For each client, the local data 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i} is a mix of data from different domains with mixed coefficients, i.e., 𝒟i=∑mπi,m​D~msubscript𝒟𝑖subscript𝑚subscript𝜋𝑖𝑚subscript~𝐷𝑚\mathcal{D}_{i}=\sum_{m}\pi_{i,m}\tilde{D}_{m}.

FedAvg: learns a single model 𝑩𝑩{\bm{B}} and 𝒘𝒘{\bm{w}} across the all clients via the following objective,

FedDAR: In contrast, in the linear case, our proposed method, FedDAR, which will be introduced next, learns a shared representation 𝑩𝑩{\bm{B}} and separate heads 𝒘msubscript𝒘𝑚{\bm{w}}_{m} for each domain m𝑚m,

min𝑩,𝒘1,⋯,𝒘m⁡12​M​∑i∈[n]∑m∈[M]πi,m∑i′πi′,m​𝔼(𝒙,y)∼𝒟~m​(y−𝒙⊤​𝑩​𝒘m)2subscript𝑩subscript𝒘1⋯subscript𝒘𝑚12𝑀subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛subscript𝑚delimited-[]𝑀subscript𝜋𝑖𝑚subscriptsuperscript𝑖′subscript𝜋superscript𝑖′𝑚subscript𝔼similar-to𝒙𝑦subscript~𝒟𝑚superscript𝑦superscript𝒙top𝑩subscript𝒘𝑚2\min_{{\bm{B}},{\bm{w}}_{1},\cdots,{\bm{w}}_{m}}\frac{1}{2M}\sum_{i\in[n]}\sum_{m\in[M]}\frac{\pi_{i,m}}{\sum_{i^{\prime}}\pi_{i^{\prime},m}}\mathbb{E}_{({\bm{x}},y)\sim\tilde{\mathcal{D}}_{m}}(y-{\bm{x}}^{\top}{\bm{B}}{\bm{w}}_{m})^{2} (4)

From the above formulations, we can see that FedAvd and FedRep are not able to achieve the zero error in our domain-mixed FL problem.

4 Proposed Method: FedDAR

To solve the Domain-mixed FL problem, we propose a new method called, Federated Domain-Aware Representation Learning (FedDAR). In the following, we first introduce the model, learning objective and the details of the federated optimization algorithm.

4.1 Algorithm Overview

Our model is made of a shared encoder ϕ​(⋅;𝜽)italic-ϕ⋅𝜽\phi(\cdot;\bm{\theta}) and M𝑀M domain specific heads hm​(⋅;𝒘m)subscriptℎ𝑚⋅subscript𝒘𝑚h_{m}(\cdot;{\bm{w}}_{m}) whose are parameterized by neural networks with the weights 𝜽𝜽\bm{\theta} and 𝒘m,∀m∈[M]subscript𝒘𝑚for-all𝑚delimited-[]𝑀{\bm{w}}_{m},\forall m\in[M]. According to our problem formation in Equation 1, our algorithm aims to solve the following optimization,

minϕ,h1,…,hM⁡ℛ​(ϕ,h1,…,hM):=1M​∑m=1Mℛm​(hm∘ϕ)assignsubscriptitalic-ϕsubscriptℎ1…subscriptℎ𝑀ℛitalic-ϕsubscriptℎ1…subscriptℎ𝑀1𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscriptℛ𝑚subscriptℎ𝑚italic-ϕ\min_{\phi,h_{1},...,h_{M}}{\mathcal{R}}(\phi,h_{1},...,h_{M}):=\frac{1}{M}\sum_{m=1}^{M}{\mathcal{R}}_{m}(h_{m}\circ\phi) (5)

We decouple the training between encoder and heads. Specifically, we alternates the learning between the encoder and the heads. The learning is done federatedly and has two conventional steps: (1) local updates; (2) aggregation at the server. Algorithm 1 shows the relevant code.

Empirical Objectives with Re-weighting. Empirically, the objectives are estimated via the finite data samples at each client. We use 𝒮i,msubscript𝒮𝑖𝑚\mathcal{S}_{i,m} to denote the set of samples from domain m𝑚m in client i𝑖i, with Li,m:=|𝒮i,m|assignsubscript𝐿𝑖𝑚subscript𝒮𝑖𝑚L_{i,m}:=|\mathcal{S}_{i,m}| denoting the sample size. Further, Li:=∑m=1MLi,massignsubscript𝐿𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscript𝐿𝑖𝑚L_{i}:=\sum_{m=1}^{M}L_{i,m} is the number of samples in client i𝑖i while Lm:=∑i=1nLi,massignsubscript𝐿𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝐿𝑖𝑚L_{m}:=\sum_{i=1}^{n}L_{i,m} is the total number of samples belonging to domain m𝑚m across all the clients. Combining commonly used weighted average FL objective ℛ^​(ϕ,h1,…,hM)=∑i=1nLiL​ℛ^i​(ϕ,h1,…,hM)^ℛitalic-ϕsubscriptℎ1…subscriptℎ𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝐿𝑖𝐿subscript^ℛ𝑖italic-ϕsubscriptℎ1…subscriptℎ𝑀\hat{{\mathcal{R}}}(\phi,h_{1},...,h_{M})=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{L_{i}}{L}\hat{{\mathcal{R}}}_{i}(\phi,h_{1},...,h_{M}), the overall empirical risk is derived as the following,

ℛ^​(ϕ,h1,…,hM):=∑i=1nLiL​ℛ^i​(ϕ,h1,…,hM)=1M​∑m=1Mℛ^m​(hm∘ϕ)assign^ℛitalic-ϕsubscriptℎ1…subscriptℎ𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝐿𝑖𝐿subscript^ℛ𝑖italic-ϕsubscriptℎ1…subscriptℎ𝑀1𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscript^ℛ𝑚subscriptℎ𝑚italic-ϕ\hat{{\mathcal{R}}}(\phi,h_{1},...,h_{M}):=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{L_{i}}{L}\hat{{\mathcal{R}}}_{i}(\phi,h_{1},...,h_{M})=\frac{1}{M}\sum_{m=1}^{M}\hat{{\mathcal{R}}}_{m}(h_{m}\circ\phi) (6)

, where ℛ^m​(hm∘ϕ):=∑i=1nLi,mLm​ℛ^i,m​(hm∘ϕ)assignsubscript^ℛ𝑚subscriptℎ𝑚italic-ϕsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝐿𝑖𝑚subscript𝐿𝑚subscript^ℛ𝑖𝑚subscriptℎ𝑚italic-ϕ\hat{{\mathcal{R}}}_{m}(h_{m}\circ\phi):=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{L_{i,m}}{L_{m}}\hat{{\mathcal{R}}}_{i,m}(h_{m}\circ\phi). This is consistent with Equation 5.

4.2 Local Updates at Clients

In each communication round, clients use gradient descent methods to optimize representation ϕ​(⋅;𝜽)italic-ϕ⋅𝜽\phi(\cdot;\bm{\theta}) and local heads hm​(⋅;𝒘m)subscriptℎ𝑚⋅subscript𝒘𝑚h_{m}(\cdot;{\bm{w}}_{m}) for m∈[M]𝑚delimited-[]𝑀m\in[M] alternately. We use t𝑡t to denote the current round. For a module f𝑓f, ft−1superscript𝑓𝑡1f^{t-1} denotes its optimized version after t−1𝑡1t-1 rounds. Each round has multiple gradient descent iterations. We use ft,ssuperscript𝑓𝑡𝑠f^{t,s} to denote the module in round t𝑡t after s𝑠s iterations. Since the updates are made locally, clients maintain their own copies of both modules, we use subscripts i𝑖i to index local copy at client i𝑖i, e.g., fit,ssubscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑡𝑠𝑖f^{t,s}_{i}. We use GRD to denote a generic gradient-base optimization step which takes three inputs: objective function, variables, learning rate and maps them into a new module with updated variables. For example, the vanilla gradient descent has the form GRD​(ℒ​(f𝒘),f𝒘,α)=f𝒘−α​∇𝒘ℒ​(f𝒘)GRDℒsubscript𝑓𝒘subscript𝑓𝒘𝛼subscript𝑓𝒘𝛼subscript∇𝒘ℒsubscript𝑓𝒘\texttt{GRD}({\mathcal{L}}(f_{{\bm{w}}}),f_{{\bm{w}}},\alpha)=f_{{\bm{w}}-\alpha\nabla_{{\bm{w}}}{\mathcal{L}}(f_{{\bm{w}}})}.

For the heads, client i𝑖i performs τhsubscript𝜏ℎ\tau_{h} local gradient-based updates to obtain optimal head given the current shared encoder ϕt−1superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑡1\phi^{t-1}. For s∈[τh]𝑠delimited-[]subscript𝜏ℎs\in[\tau_{h}], client i𝑖i updates via hi,mt,s←GRD​(ℛ^i,m​(hi,mt,s−1∘ϕt−1),hi,mt,s−1,α)←subscriptsuperscriptℎ𝑡𝑠𝑖𝑚GRDsubscript^ℛ𝑖𝑚subscriptsuperscriptℎ𝑡𝑠1𝑖𝑚superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑡1subscriptsuperscriptℎ𝑡𝑠1𝑖𝑚𝛼h^{t,s}_{i,m}\leftarrow\texttt{GRD}(\hat{{\mathcal{R}}}_{i,m}(h^{t,s-1}_{i,m}\circ\phi^{t-1}),h^{t,s-1}_{i,m},\alpha). For the shared encoder, the clients executes τϕsubscript𝜏italic-ϕ\tau_{\phi} local updates. Specifically, for s∈[τϕ]𝑠delimited-[]subscript𝜏italic-ϕs\in[\tau_{\phi}], client i𝑖i updates the local copy of the encoder via ϕit,s←GRD​(ℛ^i​(ϕit,s−1,{hmt}m=1M),ϕit,s−1,α)←subscriptsuperscriptitalic-ϕ𝑡𝑠𝑖GRDsubscript^ℛ𝑖superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑡𝑠1superscriptsubscriptsubscriptsuperscriptℎ𝑡𝑚𝑚1𝑀subscriptsuperscriptitalic-ϕ𝑡𝑠1𝑖𝛼\phi^{t,s}_{i}\leftarrow\texttt{GRD}(\hat{{\mathcal{R}}}_{i}(\phi_{i}^{t,s-1},\{h^{t}_{m}\}_{m=1}^{M}),\phi^{t,s-1}_{i},\alpha). The re-weighting mentioned in last section is implemented by re-weighting each sample with umsubscript𝑢𝑚u_{m} when calculating the loss function.

4.3 Aggregation at Server

We introduce two strategies: (1) weighted average (WA); (2) second-order aggregation (SA).

Weighted average means the aggregated model parameters are the average of the local model’s parameters weighted by the number of data samples. Specifically, for the shared encoder, we have 𝜽t=∑i=1nLiL​𝜽t−1superscript𝜽𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝐿𝑖𝐿superscript𝜽𝑡1\bm{\theta}^{t}=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{L_{i}}{L}\bm{\theta}^{t-1}. Similarly for each head, we have 𝒘mt=∑i=1nLi,mLm​𝒘m,it−1superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑚𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝐿𝑖𝑚subscript𝐿𝑚superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑚𝑖𝑡1{\bm{w}}_{m}^{t}=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{L_{i,m}}{L_{m}}{\bm{w}}_{m,i}^{t-1}.

Second-order aggregation is a more complex strategy. Ideally, we want the head aggregation generates the globally optimal model given a set of locally optimal model, as shown in the following,

𝒘∗∈arg⁡min𝒘⁡𝒥​(𝒘)≜∑i=1nαi​𝒥i​(𝒘),given​𝒘i∗=arg⁡min𝒘⁡ℛi​(𝒘)∀i∈[n].formulae-sequencesuperscript𝒘subscript𝒘𝒥𝒘≜superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝛼𝑖subscript𝒥𝑖𝒘formulae-sequencegivensuperscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖subscript𝒘subscriptℛ𝑖𝒘for-all𝑖delimited-[]𝑛{\bm{w}}^{*}\in\arg\min_{{\bm{w}}}{\mathcal{J}}({\bm{w}})\triangleq\sum_{i=1}^{n}\alpha_{i}{\mathcal{J}}_{i}({\bm{w}}),~{}~{}~{}\text{given}~{}{\bm{w}}_{i}^{*}=\arg\min_{{\bm{w}}}{\mathcal{R}}_{i}({\bm{w}})\ \ \forall i\in[n]. (7)

where 𝒥isubscript𝒥𝑖{\mathcal{J}}_{i} is i𝑖i’th client’s virtual objective, αi:=Li/Lassignsubscript𝛼𝑖subscript𝐿𝑖𝐿\alpha_{i}:=L_{i}/L is the importance of the client, Lisubscript𝐿𝑖L_{i} is the number of data samples. We call 𝒥isubscript𝒥𝑖{\mathcal{J}}_{i} the virtual objective to distinguish it from the real learning objective ℛisubscriptℛ𝑖{\mathcal{R}}_{i}. The virtual objective is defined as that the local updates give the optimal solution w.r.t it. It is introduced since the local updates during two aggregated are not guaranteed to optimize the head to optimal w.r.t the real objective. For example, if each local updates is single step gradient descent with a learning rate η𝜂\eta, i.e., 𝒘it+1=𝒘t−η​∇𝒘ℛi​(𝒘t)subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡1𝑖superscript𝒘𝑡𝜂subscript∇𝒘subscriptℛ𝑖superscript𝒘𝑡{\bm{w}}^{t+1}_{i}={\bm{w}}^{t}-\eta\nabla_{\bm{w}}{\mathcal{R}}_{i}({\bm{w}}^{t}). Then the virtual objective becomes 𝒥i​(𝒘)=ℛi​(𝒘t)+(𝒘−𝒘t)⊤​∇𝒘ℛi​(𝒘t)+12​η​‖𝒘−𝒘t‖22subscript𝒥𝑖𝒘subscriptℛ𝑖superscript𝒘𝑡superscript𝒘superscript𝒘𝑡topsubscript∇𝒘subscriptℛ𝑖superscript𝒘𝑡12𝜂superscriptsubscriptnorm𝒘superscript𝒘𝑡22{\mathcal{J}}_{i}({\bm{w}})={\mathcal{R}}_{i}({\bm{w}}^{t})+({\bm{w}}-{\bm{w}}^{t})^{\top}\nabla_{\bm{w}}{\mathcal{R}}_{i}({\bm{w}}^{t})+\frac{1}{2\eta}\|{\bm{w}}-{\bm{w}}^{t}\|_{2}^{2} which satisfies 𝒘it+1∈arg⁡min𝒘⁡𝒥i​(𝒘)subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡1𝑖subscript𝒘subscript𝒥𝑖𝒘{\bm{w}}^{t+1}_{i}\in\arg\min_{{\bm{w}}}{\mathcal{J}}_{i}({\bm{w}}). Such a virtual objective leads the solution of problem 7 to 𝒘∗=1n​∑i=1n𝒘i∗superscript𝒘1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑖{\bm{w}}^{*}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}{\bm{w}}^{*}_{i} which is the simple averaging strategy.

However, in real practice, the local updates is usually more complicated which makes the virtual objective closer to the true objective. We consider the case that the virtual objective is the second order Taylor expansion of the true objective, i.e., 𝒥​(𝒘)=ℛ​(𝒘t)+(𝒘−𝒘t)⊤​∇𝒘ℛ​(𝒘t)+12​(𝒘−𝒘t)⊤​𝑯ℛ​(𝒘t)​(𝒘−𝒘t)𝒥𝒘ℛsubscript𝒘𝑡superscript𝒘superscript𝒘𝑡topsubscript∇𝒘ℛsuperscript𝒘𝑡12superscript𝒘superscript𝒘𝑡topsubscript𝑯ℛsuperscript𝒘𝑡𝒘superscript𝒘𝑡{\mathcal{J}}({\bm{w}})={\mathcal{R}}({\bm{w}}_{t})+({\bm{w}}-{\bm{w}}^{t})^{\top}\nabla_{\bm{w}}{\mathcal{R}}({\bm{w}}^{t})+\frac{1}{2}({\bm{w}}-{\bm{w}}^{t})^{\top}{\bm{H}}_{\mathcal{R}}({\bm{w}}^{t})({\bm{w}}-{\bm{w}}^{t}) where 𝑯ℛsubscript𝑯ℛ{\bm{H}}_{\mathcal{R}} is the Hessian matrix. Then each round of local update equivalents to a Newton-like step, 𝒘it+1=𝒘t−𝑯ℛi​(𝒘t)−1​∇𝒘ℛi​(𝒘t)subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡1𝑖superscript𝒘𝑡subscript𝑯subscriptℛ𝑖superscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡1subscript∇𝒘subscriptℛ𝑖superscript𝒘𝑡{\bm{w}}^{t+1}_{i}={\bm{w}}^{t}-{\bm{H}}_{{\mathcal{R}}_{i}}({\bm{w}}^{t})^{-1}\nabla_{{\bm{w}}}{\mathcal{R}}_{i}({\bm{w}}^{t}). While 𝒘t+1=𝒘t−𝑯ℛ​(𝒘t)−1​∇𝒘ℛ​(𝒘t)superscript𝒘𝑡1superscript𝒘𝑡subscript𝑯ℛsuperscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡1subscript∇𝒘ℛsuperscript𝒘𝑡{\bm{w}}^{t+1}={\bm{w}}^{t}-{\bm{H}}_{{\mathcal{R}}}({\bm{w}}^{t})^{-1}\nabla_{{\bm{w}}}{\mathcal{R}}({\bm{w}}^{t}) is the desired globally optima. Leveraging the fact that, ∇𝒘ℛ​(𝒘)=∑i∈[n]αi​∇𝒘ℛi​(𝒘)subscript∇𝒘ℛ𝒘subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛subscript𝛼𝑖subscript∇𝒘subscriptℛ𝑖𝒘\nabla_{{\bm{w}}}{\mathcal{R}}({\bm{w}})=\sum_{i\in[n]}\alpha_{i}\nabla_{{\bm{w}}}{\mathcal{R}}_{i}({\bm{w}}) and 𝑯ℛ​(𝒘)=∑i∈[n]αi​𝑯ℛi​(𝒘)subscript𝑯ℛ𝒘subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛subscript𝛼𝑖subscript𝑯subscriptℛ𝑖𝒘{\bm{H}}_{{\mathcal{R}}}({\bm{w}})=\sum_{i\in[n]}\alpha_{i}{\bm{H}}_{{\mathcal{R}}_{i}}({\bm{w}}), we can get 𝒘t+1superscript𝒘𝑡1{\bm{w}}^{t+1} from 𝒘it+1subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡1𝑖{\bm{w}}^{t+1}_{i} via the following equation, which we call second-order aggregation,

𝒘t+1=𝑯ℛ​(𝒘t)−1​∑i∈[n]αi​𝑯ℛi​(𝒘t)​𝒘it+1superscript𝒘𝑡1subscript𝑯ℛsuperscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡1subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛subscript𝛼𝑖subscript𝑯subscriptℛ𝑖superscript𝒘𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡1𝑖{\bm{w}}^{t+1}={\bm{H}}_{{\mathcal{R}}}({\bm{w}}^{t})^{-1}\sum_{i\in[n]}\alpha_{i}{\bm{H}}_{{\mathcal{R}}_{i}}({\bm{w}}^{t}){\bm{w}}^{t+1}_{i} (8)

Note that proposed head aggregation requires sending the Hessian matrix to the server which takes a communication cost being quadratic to the size of the weight. In real practice, the predictor head is usually small, e.g., a linear layer with hundreds of neurons. Thus it is acceptable to aggregate the Hessian matrix of the head’s parameters.

In the following, we provide two instances of our second-order aggregation with a linear head.

1. Linear Regression where ℛi​(𝒘)=1Li​∑j=1Li(𝒘⊤​𝒙ij−yj)2subscriptℛ𝑖𝒘1subscript𝐿𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝐿𝑖superscriptsuperscript𝒘topsubscriptsuperscript𝒙𝑗𝑖superscript𝑦𝑗2{\mathcal{R}}_{i}({\bm{w}})=\frac{1}{L_{i}}\sum_{j=1}^{L_{i}}({\bm{w}}^{\top}{\bm{x}}^{j}_{i}-y^{j})^{2} is quadratic itself. Thus the second order taylor expansion of the objective itself, i.e., 𝒥i​(𝒘)=ℛi​(𝒘)subscript𝒥𝑖𝒘subscriptℛ𝑖𝒘{\mathcal{J}}_{i}({\bm{w}})={\mathcal{R}}_{i}({\bm{w}}). In this case, 𝑯ℛi​(𝒘)=𝑿i⊤​𝑿isubscript𝑯subscriptℛ𝑖𝒘superscriptsubscript𝑿𝑖topsubscript𝑿𝑖{\bm{H}}_{{\mathcal{R}}_{i}}({\bm{w}})={\bm{X}}_{i}^{\top}{\bm{X}}_{i} where 𝑿i=[𝒙i1,⋯,𝒙iLi]⊤subscript𝑿𝑖superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝒙1𝑖⋯subscriptsuperscript𝒙subscript𝐿𝑖𝑖top{\bm{X}}_{i}=[{\bm{x}}^{1}_{i},\cdots,{\bm{x}}^{L_{i}}_{i}]^{\top} is the data matrix of client i𝑖i.

2. Binary Classification where ℛi​(𝒘)=−1Li​∑j=1Liyij​log⁡σ​(𝒘⊤​𝒙ij)+(1−yij)​log⁡(1−σ​(𝒘⊤​𝒙ij))subscriptℛ𝑖𝒘1subscript𝐿𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝐿𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑦𝑗𝑖𝜎superscript𝒘topsubscriptsuperscript𝒙𝑗𝑖1subscriptsuperscript𝑦𝑗𝑖1𝜎superscript𝒘topsubscriptsuperscript𝒙𝑗𝑖{\mathcal{R}}_{i}({\bm{w}})=-\frac{1}{L_{i}}\sum_{j=1}^{L_{i}}y^{j}_{i}\log\sigma({\bm{w}}^{\top}{\bm{x}}^{j}_{i})+(1-y^{j}_{i})\log(1-\sigma({\bm{w}}^{\top}{\bm{x}}^{j}_{i})). σ𝜎\sigma is the sigmoid function. Let μij≜σ​(𝒘⊤​𝒙ij)≜subscriptsuperscript𝜇𝑗𝑖𝜎superscript𝒘topsubscriptsuperscript𝒙𝑗𝑖\mu^{j}_{i}\triangleq\sigma({\bm{w}}^{\top}{\bm{x}}^{j}_{i}) denote model’s output. The gradient and the Hessian are, ∇𝒘ℛi​(𝒘)=1Li​∑j(μij−yij)​𝒙ij=1Li​𝟏⊤​diag(𝝁i−yi)⁡𝑿i⊤subscript∇𝒘subscriptℛ𝑖𝒘1subscript𝐿𝑖subscript𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝜇𝑗𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑦𝑗𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝒙𝑗𝑖1subscript𝐿𝑖superscript1topdiagsubscript𝝁𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑿𝑖top\nabla_{{\bm{w}}}{\mathcal{R}}_{i}({\bm{w}})=\frac{1}{L_{i}}\sum_{j}(\mu^{j}_{i}-y^{j}_{i}){\bm{x}}^{j}_{i}=\frac{1}{L_{i}}\bm{1}^{\top}\operatorname*{diag}(\bm{\mu}_{i}-y_{i}){\bm{X}}_{i}^{\top} and 𝑯ℛi​(𝒘)=1Li​𝑿i⊤​𝑺​𝑿isubscript𝑯subscriptℛ𝑖𝒘1subscript𝐿𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑿𝑖top𝑺subscript𝑿𝑖{\bm{H}}_{{\mathcal{R}}_{i}}({\bm{w}})=\frac{1}{L_{i}}{\bm{X}}_{i}^{\top}{\bm{S}}{\bm{X}}_{i} where 𝑺≜diag(μi1​(1−μi1),⋯,μiLi​(1−μiLi))≜𝑺diagsubscriptsuperscript𝜇1𝑖1subscriptsuperscript𝜇1𝑖⋯subscriptsuperscript𝜇subscript𝐿𝑖𝑖1subscriptsuperscript𝜇subscript𝐿𝑖𝑖{\bm{S}}\triangleq\operatorname*{diag}(\mu^{1}_{i}(1-\mu^{1}_{i}),\cdots,\mu^{L_{i}}_{i}(1-\mu^{L_{i}}_{i})). Similar formulas can be derived for the multiclass classification. Please refer to the text book [41] for the exact equations.

Remark.

In practice, when the dimension of 𝒘𝒘{\bm{w}} is larger than the number of samples of certain domain, the Hessian may have small singular values which causes numerically instability. To address this, we add an additional projection layer on top of the model’s representation to reduce its dimension.

4.4 Theoretical Result of FedDAR

For a simplified linear regression setting as discussed in domain-mixed FL (4) (cf. details in Appendix A), we give below the sample complexity required for an adapted version of our algorithm (Algorithm 2 in the appendix) to enjoy linear convergence. Due to the space limit, we only provide an informal statement to highlight the result. Formal statement and the proof are deferred in the appendix.

Theorem 4.1 ( Sample complexity of FedDAR convergence in linear case (informal)).

Consider the linear setting for domain-mixed FL in (4). At each iteration, suppose that the number of samples used by each of n𝑛n clients to update the encoder, is Ω~​(d​k2n)~Ω𝑑superscript𝑘2𝑛\tilde{\Omega}(\frac{dk^{2}}{n}), and that the aggregate number of samples used in the update for the domain-specific heads, is Ω~​(k2)~Ωsuperscript𝑘2\tilde{\Omega}(k^{2}). Then, for a suitably chosen step-size, the distance between the encoder 𝐁𝐭subscript𝐁𝐭\bf{B}_{t} Algorithm 2 outputs and the true encoder 𝐁∗superscript𝐁\bf{B}^{*} converges at a linear rate.

Remark.

As our algorithm converges linearly to the true encoder, the per-iteration sample complexity of our algorithm gives a good estimate of the overall sample complexity. Since we expect the output of the encoder to be significantly lower-dimensional than the input (i.e. k≪dmuch-less-than𝑘𝑑k\ll d), our result indicates that Algorithm 2’s sample complexity is dominated by Ω~​(dn)~Ω𝑑𝑛\tilde{\Omega}(\frac{d}{n}), implying that the complexity reduces significantly as the number of clients n𝑛n increases. Moreover, a key implication of our result is the capacity for our algorithm to accommodate data imbalance across domains. We note that our approach requires Ω​(d​k2)Ω𝑑superscript𝑘2\Omega(dk^{2}) samples per iteration for the update of the shared representation 𝑩∈ℝd×k𝑩superscriptℝ𝑑𝑘{\bm{B}}\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times k}, whilst needing only Ω​(k2)Ωsuperscript𝑘2\Omega(k^{2}) samples per iteration for the update of each domain head. In particular, domains with more data can contribute disproportionately to the Ω~​(d​k2)~Ω𝑑superscript𝑘2\tilde{\Omega}(dk^{2}) samples required to learn the common representation, whilst domains with less data need only provide Ω~​(k2)~Ωsuperscript𝑘2\tilde{\Omega}(k^{2}) samples to update its domain head during the course of the algorithm. Whenever k2≪dmuch-less-thansuperscript𝑘2𝑑k^{2}\ll d, which we believe is a reasonable assumption for many practical applications (e.g. medical imaging), the requirement of Ω~​(k2)~Ωsuperscript𝑘2\tilde{\Omega}(k^{2}) samples per domain is relatively mild. Conversely, forgoing the shared representation structure would require each domain to learn a separate d𝑑d-dimensional classifier, requiring Ω~​(d)~Ω𝑑\tilde{\Omega}(d) samples per domain, which can pose a challenge in problems with domain data imbalance.

5 Experiments

We validate our method’s effectiveness on both synthetic and real datasets. We first experiment on the exact synthetic dataset described in our theoretical analysis to verify our theory. We then conduct experiments on a real dataset, FairFace [27], with controlled domain distributions to investigate the robustness of our algorithm under different levels of heterogeneity. Finally we compare our method with various baselines on a real federated learning benchmark, EXAM [9] with real-world domain distributions. We also conduct extensive ablation studies on it to discern the contribution of each component of our method. Full details of experimental settings can be found in the Appendix B.

5.1 Synthetic Data

We first run experiments on the linear regression problem analyzed in Appendix A. We generate (domain, data, label) samples as the following, zi∼ℳ​(𝝅𝒊)similar-tosubscript𝑧𝑖ℳsubscript𝝅𝒊z_{i}\sim\mathcal{M}(\bm{\pi_{i}}), 𝒙i∼𝒩​(0,𝑰d)similar-tosubscript𝒙𝑖𝒩0subscript𝑰𝑑{\bm{x}}_{i}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,{\bm{I}}_{d}), yi∼𝒩​(𝒘zi∗⊤​𝑩∗⊤​𝒙i,σ)similar-tosubscript𝑦𝑖𝒩superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝒘subscript𝑧𝑖topsuperscriptsuperscript𝑩topsubscript𝒙𝑖𝜎y_{i}\sim\mathcal{N}({{\bm{w}}_{z_{i}}^{*}}^{\top}{{\bm{B}}^{*}}^{\top}{\bm{x}}_{i},\sigma) where σ=10−3𝜎superscript103\sigma=10^{-3} controls label observation errors, ℳ​(𝝅𝒊)ℳsubscript𝝅𝒊\mathcal{M}(\bm{\pi_{i}}) is a multinomial domain distribution with parameter 𝝅𝒊=[πi,1,…,πi,M]∈ΔMsubscript𝝅𝒊subscript𝜋𝑖1…subscript𝜋𝑖𝑀superscriptΔ𝑀\bm{\pi_{i}}=[\pi_{i,1},...,\pi_{i,M}]\in\Delta^{M}. The hyper-parameters of domain distributions 𝝅𝒊subscript𝝅𝒊\bm{\pi_{i}} are drawn from a Dirichlet distribution, i.e., 𝝅𝒊∼D​i​r​(α​𝒑)similar-tosubscript𝝅𝒊𝐷𝑖𝑟𝛼𝒑\bm{\pi_{i}}\sim Dir(\alpha{\bm{p}}), where 𝒑∈ΔM𝒑superscriptΔ𝑀{\bm{p}}\in\Delta^{M} is a prior domain distribution over M𝑀M domains, and α>0𝛼0\alpha>0 is a concentration parameter controlling the heterogeneity of domain distributions among clients. The largest domain distributions heterogeneity is achieved as α→0→𝛼0\alpha\rightarrow 0 where each client contains data only from a single randomly selected domain. On the other hand, when α→∞→𝛼\alpha\rightarrow\infty, all clients have identical domain distributions that equal to the prior 𝒑𝒑{\bm{p}}. We generate ground-truth representation 𝑩∗∈ℝd×ksuperscript𝑩superscriptℝ𝑑𝑘{\bm{B}}^{*}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{d\times k} and domain specific heads 𝒘m∗,∀m∈[M]superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑚for-all𝑚delimited-[]𝑀{{\bm{w}}_{m}^{*}},\forall m\in[M] by sampling and normalizing Gaussian matrices.

Figure 2 shows result of our experiments where we set n=100𝑛100n=100 clients, M=5𝑀5M=5 domains, feature dimension k=2𝑘2k=2. We varies the number of training samples per clients from 555 to 202020. The result shows that FedDAR-SA, achieves four orders of magnitude smaller errors than all the baselines: (1) Local-Only where each client train a model using its own data; (2) FedAvg which learns a single shared model; (3) FedRep which learns shared representation and client-specific heads. The results demonstrate that our method overcomes the heterogeneity of domain distributions across clients. FedDAR-WA fails to converge under such setting, confirming the effectiveness of proposed second-order aggregation.

5.2 Real Data with Controlled Distribution

Dataset and Model. We use FairFace [27], a public face image dataset containing 7 race groups which are considered as the domains. Each image is labeled with one of 9 age groups and gender. We use the age label as the target to build a multi-class age classifier. We created a FL setting via dividing training data to n𝑛n clients without duplication. Each client has a domain distribution 𝝅𝒊∼D​i​r​(α​𝒑)similar-tosubscript𝝅𝒊𝐷𝑖𝑟𝛼𝒑\bm{\pi_{i}}\sim Dir(\alpha{\bm{p}}) sampled from a Dirichlet distribution. The total number of samples at each client Li=500subscript𝐿𝑖500L_{i}=500 is set to be the same in all experiments. We control the heterogeneity of domain distributions by altering α𝛼\alpha. The label distributions are uniform for all the clients.

Implementation and Evaluation. We use Imagenet[10] pre-trained ResNet-34 [21] for all experiments on this dataset. All the methods are trained for T=100𝑇100T=100 communication rounds. We use Adam optimizer with a learning rate of 1×10−41superscript1041\times 10^{-4} for the first 606060 rounds and 1×10−51superscript1051\times 10^{-5} for the last 404040 rounds.

Our evaluation metrics are the classification accuracy on the whole validation set of FairFace for each race group. We don’t have extra local validation set to each client since we assume the data distribution within each domain is consistent across the clients. The numbers reported are the average over the final 101010 rounds of communication following the standard practice in [6].

Table 1 report the results of our experiments. In general, our FedDAR achieved the best performance compared with the baselines.

Effect of k𝑘k. The limitation of using FedDAR-SA instead of FedDAR-WA is the need of tuning the dimension of representation k𝑘k. Figure 2 shows results of the average domain test accuracy with different k𝑘k. We can see that FedDAR-SA can achieve better accuracy with a properly chosen k𝑘k.

Robustness to Varying Levels of Heterogeneity. From the result with various α𝛼\alpha, we can observe that the performance of FedDAR-SA is very stable no matter how heterogeneous the domain mixtures are. However the baselines’ accuracy decrease when α𝛼\alpha becomes smaller.

5.3 Real Data with Real-World Data Distribution

Dataset and Model. We use the EXAM dataset [9], a large-scale, real-world healthcare FL study. We use part of the dataset including 6 clients with a total of 7,681 cases. We use race groups as domains. The dataset is collected from suspected COVID-19 patients at the visit of emergency department (ED), including both Chest X-ray (CXR) and electronic medical records (EMR). We adopt the same data preprocessing procedure and the model as [9]. Our task is to predict whether the patient received the oxygen therapy higher than high-flow oxygen in 72 hours which indicates severe symptoms.

Baselines. We compare our FedDAR against various baselines including: (1) methods that learn one global model, FedAvg[38], FedProx[31], FedMinMax[45] along with their local fine-tuned variants; (2) train M𝑀M separate models with FedAvg; (3) train one global model with FedAvg fisrt, then fine-tune on M𝑀M domains separately with FedAvg; (4) client-wise personalized FL approaches, FedRep[6], FedPer[1], LG-Fedavg[34].

Implementation and Evaluation. We apply 5-fold cross validation. All the models are trained for T=20𝑇20T=20 communication rounds with Adam optimizer and a learning rate of 1×10−41superscript1041\times 10^{-4}. The models are evaluated by aggregating predictions on the local validation sets then calculating the area under curve (AUC) for each domain. The average AUCs on local validation set of clients are also reported.

Average Performance Across Domains and Clients. Table 3 shows the average of AUCs across domains and clients. We can see that our methods, both FedDAR-WA and FedDAR-SA, achieve significantly better performance than all the baselines under both domain-wise and client-wise metrics. The gap between our domain-wise personalized approach and other client-wise personalized baselines shows the validity of learning domain-wise personalized model facing the diversity across domains. The reason that fine-tuning methods induce worse result is mainly because of the imbalanced label distribution. Each local training dataset doesn’t have enough positive cases to do proper fine-tuning.

Fairness Across Domains. The AUCs of each specific domain in Table 3, show that our proposed FedDAR  method uniformly increases the AUC for each domain. The column of the minimum AUC among domains also verifies that our method indeed improve the fairness across the domains.

Ablation Studies. i) re-weighting (RW): First two rows in Table 2 shows adding sample re-weighting can significantly improve the fairness across the domains. The minimum AUC among domains is improved by a large margin (>0.05absent0.05>0.05); ii) multi-head (MH), domain as input feautre (DI) and alternating update (Alter): Comparing three blocks in Table 2, we can see that adding multi-head itself cannot bring any improvement. We conjecture that alternating update prevents the overfitting of the heads with limited samples .This can also be reflected by the result in Table 1, where FedAvg+MH tends to perform badly on certain underrepresented domain especially when domain distributions are highly heterogeneous (α𝛼\alpha is small). Meanwhile, using domain labels directly as feature input is not as good as multi-head, and not compatible with alternating update; iii) projection (Proj) and aggregation method (AGG): Results in Table 2 shows that using second-order aggregation with the projection of the features gives the best result.

6 Conclusions

In this paper, we propose a novel domain-aware personalized federated learning framework based on the mixture of domain data distribution assumption. Our FedDAR approach is able to learn a global representation as well as domain-specific heads with balanced performance for each domain despite the heterogeneity of domain distributions across the clients. We provide both theoretical and empirical justification for its effectiveness. Our method is tested with face recognition task and a real-world medical imaging FL dataset, and can be easily extended to other complicated tasks like object detection and semantic segmentation due to its simplicity and flexibility.

The limitations of our method include: i) the domain information for all samples is required to be known; ii) the heterogeneity of label distributions is not considered; iii) the extra communication cost of sending Hessian matrices can be expensive, especially when output dimension is big. We plan to address these issues in the future work. Other future research directions include further boosting the fairness across domains and study the setting where domains are structured, hierarchical, continuously indexed [57, 42] or multi-dimensional (characterized by multiple factors) [57].

Appendix A FedDAR for Linear Representation

A.1 Setup

We retain the setup for linear regression considered at the start of Section 3.1. We additionally define 𝑾∗≜[𝒘1∗,⋯,𝒘M∗]⊤∈ℝM×k≜superscript𝑾superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝒘1⋯superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑀topsuperscriptℝ𝑀𝑘{\bm{W}}^{*}\triangleq[{\bm{w}}_{1}^{*},\cdots,{\bm{w}}_{M}^{*}]^{\top}\in\mathbb{R}^{M\times k} as the concatenation of domain specific heads. For notational convenience, we let (𝒙i,m,yi,m)subscript𝒙𝑖𝑚subscript𝑦𝑖𝑚({\bm{x}}_{i,m},y_{i,m}) denote an (input, output) sample coming from client i𝑖i and the m𝑚m-th domain. To measure the distance between any two matrices 𝑨,𝑩𝑨𝑩{\bm{A}},{\bm{B}} with the same dimensions, we use the principal angle distance [17], given by dist​(𝑨,𝑩)≜∥𝑨⊥⊤​𝑩∥2≜dist𝑨𝑩subscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptsubscript𝑨bottomtop𝑩2\mathrm{dist}({\bm{A}},{\bm{B}})\triangleq\lVert{\bm{A}}_{\bot}^{\top}{\bm{B}}\rVert_{2}, where 𝑨⊥subscript𝑨bottom{\bm{A}}_{\bot} denotes a matrix whose columns form a basis for the orthogonal complement of the range of 𝑨𝑨{\bm{A}}. To simplify analysis, we further make the following assumptions.

Assumption A.1 (Sub-Gaussianilty).

For each m∈[M]𝑚delimited-[]𝑀m\in[M] and i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n], the samples 𝒙i,m∈ℝdsubscript𝒙𝑖𝑚superscriptℝ𝑑{\bm{x}}_{i,m}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} are independent, mean zero, have covariance 𝑰dsubscript𝑰𝑑{\bm{I}}_{d}, and has subgaussian norm 1, i.e. for every 𝒗∈ℝd𝒗superscriptℝ𝑑{\bm{v}}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, 𝔼​[exp⁡(𝒗⊤​𝒙i,m)]≤exp⁡(∥𝒗∥2/2)𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝒗topsubscript𝒙𝑖𝑚superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝒗22\mathbb{E}[\exp({\bm{v}}^{\top}{\bm{x}}_{i,m})]\leq\exp(\lVert{\bm{v}}\rVert^{2}/2).

Assumption A.2 (Domain diversity).

Let σmin,∗≜σmin​(1M​𝑾∗)≜subscript𝜎subscript𝜎1𝑀superscript𝑾\sigma_{\min,*}\triangleq\sigma_{\min}(\frac{1}{\sqrt{M}}{\bm{W}}^{*}), i.e., σmin,∗subscript𝜎\sigma_{\min,*} is the minimum singular value of the head matrix. Then σmin,∗>0subscript𝜎0\sigma_{\min,*}>0.

Assumption A.3 (Ground truth normalization).

The true domain parameters satisfy 12​k≤∥𝒘m∗∥≤k12𝑘delimited-∥∥superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑚𝑘\frac{1}{2}\sqrt{k}\leq\lVert{\bm{w}}_{m}^{*}\rVert\leq\sqrt{k} for each m∈[M]𝑚delimited-[]𝑀m\in[M], and 𝑩∗superscript𝑩{\bm{B}}^{*} has orthonormal columns.

All the above assumptions aim to simplify the theoretical analysis whilst only imposing mild constraints on the data distribution and the parameters of the target functions. Similar assumptions have also been adapted in prior work [6].

A.2 FedDAR Adapted to Linear Regression

We analyze an adapted version of our FedDAR algorithm. Since the linear regression problem has an analytic solution, to ease analysis, we update the heads {𝒘m}m=1Msuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝒘𝑚𝑚1𝑀\{{\bm{w}}_{m}\}_{m=1}^{M} at the server in closed form using local gradient information. Meanwhile, we update the representation 𝑩𝑩{\bm{B}} by taking a step using the averaged local gradients. Algorithm 2 shows the procedure of this adapted version.

The local objective

for i𝑖i-th client in m𝑚m-th domain at t𝑡t-th iteration, fi,mt​(𝒘m,𝑩t)superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖𝑚𝑡subscript𝒘𝑚superscript𝑩𝑡f_{i,m}^{t}({\bm{w}}_{m},{\bm{B}}^{t}) is defined as the following,

fi,mt​(𝒘m,𝑩t)≜12​∑j=1Li,mt(yi,mj−𝒘m⊤​𝑩⊤​𝒙i,mj)2,≜superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖𝑚𝑡subscript𝒘𝑚superscript𝑩𝑡12superscriptsubscript𝑗1superscriptsubscript𝐿𝑖𝑚𝑡superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑦𝑖𝑚𝑗superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑚topsuperscript𝑩topsuperscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖𝑚𝑗2\displaystyle f_{i,m}^{t}({\bm{w}}_{m},{\bm{B}}^{t})\triangleq\frac{1}{2}\sum_{j=1}^{L_{i,m}^{t}}(y_{i,m}^{j}-{\bm{w}}_{m}^{\top}{\bm{B}}^{\top}{\bm{x}}_{i,m}^{j})^{2},

where Li,mtsuperscriptsubscript𝐿𝑖𝑚𝑡L_{i,m}^{t} is the number of samples from domain m𝑚m at client i𝑖i. We assume in each iteration the data points {𝒙i,mj,yi,mj}j∈[Li,mt]subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖𝑚𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑖𝑚𝑗𝑗delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝐿𝑖𝑚𝑡\{{\bm{x}}_{i,m}^{j},y_{i,m}^{j}\}_{j\in[L_{i,m}^{t}]} are all newly sampled from the distribution. After every global update of the representation 𝑩𝑩{\bm{B}}, we apply an additional QR decomposition to normalize it to be column-wise orthogonal.

A.3 Convergence Analysis

We first present a theorem that states our adapted FedDAR(Algorithm 2) enjoys linear convergence. The theorem is followed by multiple remarks which highlight key detailed points of our convergence result.

Theorem A.4 (Algorithm 2 convergence).

Initialization of 𝑩0superscript𝑩0{\bm{B}}^{0}:

For our convergence result to be meaningful, we need dist​(𝑩0,𝑩∗)distsuperscript𝑩0superscript𝑩\mathrm{dist}({\bm{B}}^{0},{\bm{B}}^{*}) to be close to 0. We show in Appendix A that our algorithm’s choice of initial 𝑩0superscript𝑩0{\bm{B}}^{0} ensures that dist​(𝑩0,𝑩∗)distsuperscript𝑩0superscript𝑩\mathrm{dist}({\bm{B}}^{0},{\bm{B}}^{*}) is close enough to 0 whilst preserving privacy. When the number of samples is uniform across the domains, this comes only at the cost of a logarithmic increase in sample complexity.

Sample complexity:

The per-iteration sample complexity per client is L𝐿L. We note that in the requirement for L𝐿L (9), we need that L≥Ω​(d​k2​κ4/n)𝐿Ω𝑑superscript𝑘2superscript𝜅4𝑛L\geq\Omega(dk^{2}\kappa^{4}/n); this comes from the updates for 𝑩t∈ℝd×ksuperscript𝑩𝑡superscriptℝ𝑑𝑘{\bm{B}}^{t}\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times k}. While we expect that d𝑑d could be large, a large number of clients n𝑛n helps to mitigate the increase in sample complexity arising from d𝑑d. We also need L≥Ω​(k2​κ4​∑i=1mπi,m)𝐿Ωsuperscript𝑘2superscript𝜅4superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝜋𝑖𝑚L\geq\Omega(k^{2}\kappa^{4}\sum_{i=1}^{m}\pi_{i,m}) for every domain m∈[M]𝑚delimited-[]𝑀m\in[M]; this requirement comes from the updates for 𝒘mtsuperscriptsubscript𝒘𝑚𝑡{\bm{w}}_{m}^{t} for each of the M𝑀M domains.

A.4.4 Combining earlier argument: convergence of FedDAR

As seen in Lemma A.8, we require that Lmin:=minm∈[M]⁡Lmassignsubscript𝐿subscript𝑚delimited-[]𝑀subscript𝐿𝑚L_{\min}:=\min_{m\in[M]}L_{m} to be lower bounded. However, since Lmsubscript𝐿𝑚L_{m} is a stochastic variable, we are unable to directly lower bound it. Below, we provide a result that converts a lower bound on each client’s sample size L𝐿L (a deterministic quantity we can control) to a high-probability lower bound on Lminsubscript𝐿L_{\min}.

Lemma A.10.

Let Lmin:=minm∈[M]⁡Lmassignsubscript𝐿subscript𝑚delimited-[]𝑀subscript𝐿𝑚L_{\min}:=\min_{m\in[M]}L_{m}. For any α>0𝛼0\alpha>0, suppose that for each m∈[M]𝑚delimited-[]𝑀m\in[M],

Lemma A.11 (Descent lemma).

Define E0:=1−dist2​(𝐁0,𝐁∗)assignsubscript𝐸01superscriptdist2superscript𝐁0superscript𝐁E_{0}:=1-\mathrm{dist}^{2}({\bm{B}}^{0},{\bm{B}}^{*}) and σ¯max,∗:=σmax​(1M​W∗)assignsubscript¯𝜎subscript𝜎1𝑀superscript𝑊\bar{\sigma}_{\max,*}:=\sigma_{\max}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{M}}W^{*}\right) and σ¯min,∗:=σmin​(1M​W∗)assignsubscript¯𝜎subscript𝜎1𝑀superscript𝑊\bar{\sigma}_{\min,*}:=\sigma_{\min}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{M}}W^{*}\right). This then yields the following convergence result, which is a more complete statement of A.4.

The argument follows the proof of Theorem 3 in [54].

where we recall that κ:=σ¯max,∗/σ¯min,∗assign𝜅subscript¯𝜎subscript¯𝜎\kappa:=\bar{\sigma}_{\max,*}/\bar{\sigma}_{\min,*}, and

σ¯max,∗:=σmax​(1M​W∗),σ¯min,∗:=σmin​(1M​W∗).formulae-sequenceassignsubscript¯𝜎subscript𝜎1𝑀superscript𝑊assignsubscript¯𝜎subscript𝜎1𝑀superscript𝑊\displaystyle\bar{\sigma}_{\max,*}:=\sigma_{\max}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{M}}W^{*}\right),\quad\bar{\sigma}_{\min,*}:=\sigma_{\min}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{M}}W^{*}\right).
Proof.

We omit the proof since it is a slight variant of Theorem 3 in [54]. For completeness, note that in the case when the number of samples is uniform across the domains, some algebra shows that

dist​(𝑩0,𝑩∗)2≤O~​(κ2​k2​dσ¯min,∗2​n​L0).distsuperscriptsuperscript𝑩0superscript𝑩2~𝑂superscript𝜅2superscript𝑘2𝑑superscriptsubscript¯𝜎2𝑛superscript𝐿0\displaystyle\mathrm{dist}({\bm{B}}^{0},{\bm{B}}^{*})^{2}\leq\tilde{O}\left(\frac{\kappa^{2}k^{2}d}{\bar{\sigma}_{\min,*}^{2}nL^{0}}\right).

which proves the last statement in the theorem.

∎

Appendix B Additional Experimental Results

B.1 Experiments on FairFace dataset for gender classification

We also conduct experiments for gender classification on FairFace with the same settings. The best representation dimension is k=2𝑘2k=2 for this task, probably due to the smaller diversity across the domains. We can see that the results shown in Table 4 have similar trend with the results in Table 1.

B.2 Experiments on digits dataset

We perform additional experiments on digits dataset with five data domains with feature shift [33]. Details are described in the following paragraphs. From Table 5, we can see that FedDAR-WA outperform FedAvg consistently except the case where domain distributions are extremely heterogeneous (α=0.1𝛼0.1\alpha=0.1). In this case, each client tends to have data from only one domain. It is difficult for the proposed method to learn a good domain-specific head for the domain with the most different data (more obvious feature shift) under this circumstance. For other levels of heterogeneity, although the min and max domain accuracies are similar between FedAvg and FedDAR-WA, the average accuracies are improved as a result of domain-wise personalized model. One the other hand, without alternative update of the head and representation, FedAvg + Multi-head will overfit quickly. We don’t include the results of FedDAR-SA here because using representation dimension k≥64𝑘64k\geq 64 causes numerical instability during head aggregation and failure to converge. While using representation dimension k≤32𝑘32k\leq 32 leads to lower accuracy.

Datasets.

We use the same digits dataset containing five different data domains as [33]. Specifically, we use SVHN [43], USPS [23], SynthDigits [15], MNIST-M [15] and MNIST [29] as five data domains. Similarity to the experiments on FairFace datraset, the training data is divided into n𝑛n clients without duplication. Each client has a domain distribution 𝝅𝒊∼D​i​r​(α​𝒑)similar-tosubscript𝝅𝒊𝐷𝑖𝑟𝛼𝒑\bm{\pi_{i}}\sim Dir(\alpha{\bm{p}}) sampled from a Dirichlet distribution.

Implementation Details.

We adapt the codebase from [33]. A 6-layer CNN with 3 convolutional layers and 3 fully-connected layers is used, with the last layer as domain-specific head. We use SGD optimizer with learning rate 10−2superscript10210^{-2} and cross-entropy loss. The batch size is set to 323232, and the total communication rounds is set to 100100100. For each method, we first train the model for 101010 rounds with 111 local epoch using FedAvg as warmup. The accuracy shown is the average over the last ten communication rounds. We repeat experiment for each setting three times with different random seeds and report the averages.

B.3 Further experimental details

B.3.1 Synthetic Data

For the synthetic data experiments, we adapt the code from [6] and follow a similar protocol. The ground-truth matrices 𝑾∗∈ℝM×ksuperscript𝑾superscriptℝ𝑀𝑘{\bm{W}}^{*}\in\mathbb{R}^{M\times k} and 𝑩∗∈ℝd×ksuperscript𝑩superscriptℝ𝑑𝑘{\bm{B}}^{*}\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times k} are generated following the same way as [6] by sampling each element from i.i.d. standard normal distribution and taking the QR factorization. The same L𝐿L samples are used for each client during the whole training process. Test samples are generated in the same way as the traning samples but without noise. For all the methods, models are initalized with ramdom Gaussian samples. We set α=0.4𝛼0.4\alpha=0.4 for experiments in Figure 2.

B.3.2 Real data with controlled distribution

Implementation details.

We use Imagenet[10] pre-trained ResNet-34 [21] for all experiments on this dataset. All the methods are trained for T=100𝑇100T=100 communication rounds, with 202020 rounds of FedAvg as warmup. We use Adam optimizer with a learning rate of 1×10−41superscript1041\times 10^{-4} for the first 606060 rounds and 1×10−51superscript1051\times 10^{-5} for the last 404040 rounds. The images are resized to 224×224224224224\times 224 with only random horizontal flip for augmentation.

Our evaluation metrics are the classification accuracy on the whole validation set of FairFace for each race group. We don’t have extra local validation set to each client since we assume the data distribution within each domain is consistent across the clients. The numbers reported are the average over the final 101010 rounds of communication following the standard practice in [6], and the average of three independent runs with different random seeds.

B.3.3 Real data with real-World data distribution

Dataset details.

The detailed statistics of the partial EXAM dataset is summarized in Table 6. The "Other" category includes American Indian or Alaska native, native Hawaiian or other Pacific islander and patients with more than one race or unknown race. ≥\geqHFO % means the percentage of cases with positive labels (receiving oxygen therapy higher or equal to high-flow oxygen with 72 hours).

Implementation details.

We apply 5-fold cross validation. All the models are trained for T=20𝑇20T=20 communication rounds with Adam optimizer and a learning rate of 1×10−41superscript1041\times 10^{-4}. For each round we do 111 local epoch for all the methods. For all the methods, the models are initialized with the same pretrained model as in [9] without any warmup. For FedDAR-SA and FedDAR-WA, we excute 5 epochs of update for heads on each round, and set representation dimension k=16𝑘16k=16 for FedDAR-SA. For FedRep,FedDARand FedPer. For LG-FedAvg, we treated the last fully-connected layer as the global parameters and all other layers as local representation. For FedMinMax, multiple local iterations are executed during each round instead of one step of GD for reasonable comparison. For FedProx we tuned μ𝜇\mu among {0.05,0.1,0.25,0.5}0.050.10.250.5\{0.05,0.1,0.25,0.5\} and used μ=0.1𝜇0.1\mu=0.1. For the fine-tuning methods, we only fine-tune the global trained model locally with Adam optimizer and learning rate of 5​e−55𝑒55e-5 for 1 epoch since more epochs of fine-tuning leads to worse results.

The models are evaluated by aggregating predictions on the local validation sets then calculating the area under curve (AUC) for each domain. The average AUCs on local validation set of clients are also reported. The AUC shown is first averaged over the last five communication rounds, and then averaged over five runs of 5-fold cross validation.
